parts.title: Part 1: Short Conversations
parts.instruction: You will hear people talking in eight different situations. For questions 1-8, choose the best answer (A, B or C).

questions.audio_description: A woman is talking to her colleague about a meeting.
questions.transcript:
Woman: Did you hear? The marketing meeting has been moved from 2pm to 4pm. The director had a last-minute conflict with the original time.
Man: Oh, that's actually better for me. I have a client call at 2:30 that I was worried about.
Woman: Great. See you at four then.
questions.question: Why was the meeting time changed?

options.B: The man requested a later time.
options.C: The meeting room was not available.

questions.audio_description: You hear a weather forecast on the radio.
questions.transcript: Announcer: Good morning, listeners. Today we're looking at a mostly cloudy day with temperatures around 15 degrees. There's a 60% chance of rain in the afternoon, so don't forget your umbrella if you're heading out later. Tomorrow looks much better though, with sunshine expected throughout the day.
questions.question: What does the forecast say about tomorrow?

questions.audio_description: A customer is speaking to a shop assistant.
questions.transcript:
Customer: Excuse me, I bought this jacket last week, but when I got home I noticed this small tear near the pocket. I'd like to exchange it for the same one, please.
Assistant: I'm sorry about that. Do you have your receipt?
Customer: Yes, here it is.
questions.question: What is the customer's problem?

options.A: The jacket is the wrong size.
options.C: The jacket is the wrong color.

questions.audio_description: You hear a message on an answering machine.
questions.transcript: Hello, this is Dr. Patterson's office calling to confirm your appointment for Thursday at 10am. If you need to reschedule, please call us back at 555-0123 before Wednesday afternoon.
questions.question: What is the purpose of this call?

questions.audio_description: Two friends are discussing weekend plans.
questions.transcript:
Man: So, are you still coming to the barbecue on Saturday?
Woman: I'd love to, but I have to finish a report for Monday. I've been putting it off all week.
Man: That's too bad. Maybe we can meet up for coffee on Sunday instead?
Woman: That would be great. Let's say 2 o'clock at the usual place?
questions.question: Why can't the woman go to the barbecue?

options.C: She is going to a coffee shop.

questions.audio_description: A travel agent is giving information.
questions.transcript: Agent: The flight departs at 7:15 in the morning and arrives in Paris at 9:30 local time. You'll have a two-hour layover in Amsterdam. The total cost including taxes is $450.
questions.question: Where will the plane stop before Paris?

questions.audio_description: A professor is making an announcement.
questions.transcript: Professor: Before we end today's class, I want to remind everyone that the deadline for the research paper has been extended by one week. It's now due on the 25th instead of the 18th. However, I still encourage you to submit early if you can.
questions.question: What has the professor announced?

questions.audio_description: A woman is talking about her new job.
questions.transcript: Woman: I started my new job last Monday. The office is only a 10-minute walk from my apartment, which is so much better than my hour-long commute before. The work is challenging but interesting.
questions.question: What does the woman like about her new job?

parts.title: Part 2: Sentence Completion
parts.instruction: You will hear a talk about the history of coffee. For questions 9-18, complete the sentences.
parts.audio_description: A lecturer giving a talk about the history of coffee.
parts.transcript:
Good afternoon, everyone. Today I'm going to talk about the fascinating history of coffee.

The story of coffee begins in Ethiopia, where, according to legend, a goat herder named Kaldi noticed his goats becoming energetic after eating berries from a certain tree. This discovery dates back to approximately the 9th century.

From Ethiopia, coffee spread to the Arabian Peninsula. By the 15th century, coffee was being grown in Yemen, and it had become an important part of social and religious life. Coffee houses, known as qahveh khaneh, began to appear in cities throughout the Middle East.

Europeans first encountered coffee in the 17th century when Venetian traders brought it to Italy. Initially, some people were suspicious and called it 'the bitter invention of Satan.' However, Pope Clement the Eighth gave coffee his approval.

The Dutch were the first Europeans to establish coffee plantations in their colonies, starting in Java, Indonesia, in the late 1600s.

Coffee reached the Americas in the 18th century. Americans switched from tea to coffee after the Boston Tea Party in 1773 as a patriotic gesture.

Today, coffee is the second most traded commodity in the world after oil. Over 2.25 billion cups are consumed every day. The largest producer of coffee is Brazil.

questions.question: According to legend, coffee was discovered by a _____ herder.
Coffee originated in the country of _____.
By the 15th century, coffee was being grown in _____.
Coffee houses in the Middle East were called qahveh _____.
Coffee was first brought to Europe by _____ traders.
The Pope who approved coffee was Clement the _____.
The Dutch established coffee plantations in _____, Indonesia.
Americans switched from tea to coffee after the Boston Tea _____.
Coffee is the second most traded commodity after _____.
The largest coffee producer in the world is _____.

parts.title: Part 3: Multiple Matching
parts.instruction: You will hear five people talking about learning a foreign language. For questions 19-23, choose from the list (A-H).
parts.audio_description: Five people talking about learning a foreign language.

speakers.name: Speaker 1
speakers.transcript: When I moved to Spain for work, I was forced to learn Spanish quickly. The best thing I did was completely immerse myself - I stopped watching English TV and only listened to Spanish radio. Within six months, I was dreaming in Spanish!

speakers.name: Speaker 2
speakers.transcript: I tried so many language apps and courses, but what really worked for me was finding a language exchange partner. We meet twice a week - one day we speak only German, the next only English. It's free, and I've made a great friend.

speakers.name: Speaker 3
speakers.transcript: Grammar books and vocabulary lists never worked for me. I learned French by watching French films with French subtitles. It was entertainment and education at the same time.

speakers.name: Speaker 4
speakers.transcript: The biggest mistake I made was being afraid to speak. I spent years perfecting my written Japanese but couldn't hold a conversation. Now I force myself to speak, even if I make mistakes. That's when I really started improving.

speakers.name: Speaker 5
speakers.transcript: I've been learning Mandarin for five years, and what kept me motivated was setting clear goals. First it was ordering food, then having a simple conversation, then reading news articles.

options.A: suggests that making mistakes is part of the learning process
options.C: believes total immersion is the most effective method
options.D: emphasizes the importance of setting achievable targets
options.E: thinks traditional learning methods are best
options.F: values the social aspect of language learning
options.G: suggests learning is easier for children
options.H: believes language learning requires expensive courses

parts.title: Part 4: Interview
parts.instruction: You will hear an interview with a marine biologist. For questions 24-30, choose the best answer (A, B or C).
parts.audio_description: An interview with Dr. Sarah Chen, a marine biologist.
parts.transcript:
Interviewer: Today we're joined by Dr. Sarah Chen, a marine biologist who has spent the last fifteen years studying ocean ecosystems.

Dr. Chen: Thank you for having me.

Interviewer: How would you describe the current state of our oceans?

Dr. Chen: Our oceans are in crisis. We're seeing coral bleaching events more frequent than ever. Fish populations are declining due to overfishing. And perhaps most concerning is the plastic pollution problem - there's now plastic in every part of the ocean.

Interviewer: What do you think is the biggest threat?

Dr. Chen: If I had to choose one, I'd say climate change. Rising ocean temperatures affect everything - they cause coral bleaching, change fish migration patterns, affect the entire food chain. And as the oceans warm, they absorb more carbon dioxide, which makes them more acidic.

Interviewer: What can ordinary people do?

Dr. Chen: Reducing plastic use is important. Being careful about what seafood you buy matters too. But perhaps the most impactful thing is using your voice - support policies that protect marine areas, vote for leaders who take climate change seriously.

Interviewer: Are there success stories?

Dr. Chen: Absolutely. When we protect areas properly, nature can recover remarkably quickly. I've seen damaged coral reefs begin to recover within a few years.

Interviewer: What's next for your research?

Dr. Chen: I'm currently leading a project to map microplastic distribution in the Pacific Ocean.

questions.question: How long has Dr. Chen been studying ocean ecosystems?
According to Dr. Chen, what is now found everywhere in the ocean?
What does Dr. Chen consider the biggest threat to ocean health?
What happens when oceans absorb more carbon dioxide?
What is the most impactful action for ordinary people?
What does Dr. Chen say about coral reefs?

options.B: They can recover quickly when protected.
options.C: They are not affected by climate change.

questions.question: What is Dr. Chen's current research about?
